sols_html:
The variance for a discrete random variable is defined to be

\[\begin{aligned} \operatorname{Var}(X) = \sum_{x_{i}}(x_{i} - \mu)^{2}P(X = x_{i})\end{aligned}\]

where the values \(x_{i}\), are the possible outcomes for the random variable \(X\) and \(\mu\) is the mean:

\[\begin{aligned} \mu = \sum_{x_{i}}x_{i}P(X = x_{i}).\end{aligned}\]

In this case, there are only two possible outcomes \(X = 0\) or \(X = 1\). If we define the probability \(P(X = 1)\) with \(p\) then by the law that the sum of the probabilities for all events must sum to one, we know that \(P(X = 0) = 1 - P(X = 1) = 1 - p\). Thus,

\[\begin{aligned} \,\mu = 0P(X = 0) + 1P(X = 1) = p.\end{aligned}\]

Now we can use the definition of variance and get an equation for \(p\).

\[\begin{aligned} \operatorname{Var}(X) = (0-p)^{2}\underbrace{P(X = 0)}_{=1-p} + (1 - p)^{2}P(X = 1) &= 1/4 \\ -p^{2}(1 - p) + (1 - p)^{2}p &= 1/4 \\ -p^{2} + p - 1/4 &= 0\\ p^{2} - p + 1/4 &= 0 \\ (p - 1/2)^{2} &= 0\end{aligned}\]

Thus, the value of \(p\) such that Var(X) = 1/4 is \(p = 1/2\).
